chapter.htmlHeader: How should head lice infestation be confirmed?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Detection combing (the systematic combing of the hair with a fine-toothed head lice detection comb) is the most reliable way to confirm the presence of head lice, and it is much more reliable than visual inspection.
    • Detection combing can be done on wet or dry hair.
    • Less preparation is needed to comb dry hair, but wet combing is more accurate because lice remain motionless when wet.
  • A live louse must be found in order to confirm active head lice infestation.
    • An itching scalp is not sufficient to diagnose active infestation.
    • The presence of louse eggs alone, whether hatched (nits) or unhatched, does not indicate active infestation.
    • Lice found using detection combing at home can be attached to sticky tape and brought to the consultation to aid diagnosis.
  • All members of the household and close contacts should also be checked for head lice.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Wet detection combing method
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Wet combing is the systematic combing of wet hair with a fine-toothed detection comb to confirm the presence of head lice. It is also used as a treatment for head lice.
    • The detection comb should be made entirely of good quality plastic (metal combs are too harsh and may pull out hair) and have teeth between 0.2–0.3 mm apart to trap head lice and their nymphs effectively [PHMEG, 2012; UKMI Cymru Wales, 2014].
      • The Bug Buster® comb is the only head lice detection (and removal) comb that has been evaluated in randomized controlled trials (using the Bug Busting® wet combing method) [Roberts et al, 2000; Hill et al, 2005]. It is available on the NHS.
      • The Hedrin® detection comb is not available on the NHS but can be purchased over-the-counter.
    • Combs primarily for egg and nit removal (nit combs) are not suitable for use as louse detection combs because their teeth are usually less than a width of a nit apart to exert traction. This is too close for louse detection because lice trapped between the teeth remain unseen and can be combed back onto the head unharmed [Ibarra, 2008].
  • Wet detection combing takes 10–15 minutes per head, depending on hair length and type. Detailed information on wet combing using the Bug Buster® comb is packed in the Bug Buster® kit and is also available from Community Hygiene Concern(www.chc.org). Information on wet detection combing using the Hedrin® detection comb is printed on the product packaging. Generally:
    • To prepare the hair for wet detection combing, the family/carer of the person with suspected head lice should [PHMEG, 2012; UKMI Cymru Wales, 2014]:
      • Wash the hair using an ordinary shampoo.
      • Apply ample hair conditioner (to aid straightening and untangling of the hair).
      • Straighten and untangle the wet hair using a wide-toothed comb.
      • Switch to a detection comb once the wide-toothed comb is able to move freely through the hair without dragging.
    • To perform wet detection combing, they should [PHMEG, 2012; UKMI Cymru Wales, 2014]
      • Slot the teeth of the detection comb into the hair at the roots so it is touching the scalp.
      • Draw the detection comb through to the tips of the hair, maintaining contact with the scalp as long as possible.
      • Check the comb for lice after each stroke, and remove them by wiping or rinsing the comb (good lighting is essential, and a magnifying glass may help).
      • Work through the hair in sections until the whole head of hair has been combed thoroughly.
      • Rinse out the conditioner.
      • Repeat the combing procedure to check for any lice that might have been missed the first time.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Dry detection combing method
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Dry combing is the systematic combing of dry hair with a fine-toothed head lice detection comb to confirm the presence of head lice.

  • The detection comb should be made entirely of good quality plastic (metal combs are too harsh and may pull out hair) and have teeth between 0.2–0.3 mm apart to trap head lice and their nymphs effectively [PHMEG, 2012; UKMI Cymru Wales, 2014].
    • The comparative sensitivity of dry combing and wet combing with conditioner for diagnosis has been evaluated using the Bug Buster® comb; wet combing with conditioner was found to be more sensitive than dry combing [Lapeere, 2007]. The Bug Buster® comb is available on the NHS.
    • The Hedrin® detection comb is not available on the NHS but can be purchased over-the-counter.
  • Combs primarily for egg and nit removal (nit combs) are not suitable for use as louse detection combs because their teeth are usually less than a width of a nit apart to exert traction. This is too close for louse detection because lice trapped between the teeth remain unseen and can be combed back onto the head unharmed [Ibarra, 2008].

Dry detection combing takes 3–5 minutes per head, depending on hair length and type:

  • To prepare the hair for dry detection combing, the family/carer of the person with suspected head lice should:
    • Switch to the detection comb once the wide-toothed comb is able to move freely through the hair without dragging.
    • Straighten and untangle the dry hair using an ordinary wide-toothed comb.
    • To perform dry detection combing, they should:
      • Comb the hair from the crown to the tips of the hairs, working all around the head.
      • Comb each section of hair 3–4 times before moving to an adjacent section.
      • Look for lice as the comb is drawn through the hair. If a possible louse is seen, the person should trap it against the face of the comb using the thumb. This avoids the risk of the louse being repelled by static electricity as the comb is withdrawn from the hair.
      • Continue combing the hair in sections until the whole head of hair is combed through.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Detection combing

  • There is evidence to show that wet combing with conditioner, dry combing, and combing lubricated dry hair (conditioned combing) are more effective and more reliable head lice detection methods than direct visual inspection (by parting the hair) [De Maeseneer et al, 2000; Mumcuoglu et al, 2001; Balcioglu et al, 2008; Jahnke et al, 2009], and expert opinion in the Public Health Medicine Environmental Group (PHMEG) guideline Head lice: evidence-based guidelines based on the Stafford Report 2012 is that if detection combing is not used as the diagnostic criterion, a misdiagnosis may occur [PHMEG, 2012].
  • CKS found no studies published in peer-reviewed journals that compared the effectiveness of dry combing with wet combing to detect head lice. However:
    • Expert opinion in the UK Medicines Information (UKMi) Cymru Wales guideline Headlice: questions and answers for healthcare professionals is that although wetting the hair is not essential, it may be useful for people with very thick hair and to prevent the build up of static electricity, which can help transmission of lice by ejecting them from the surface of combs as they are pulled out from the hairs [UKMI Cymru Wales, 2014].
    • Advice by Community Hygiene Concern (www.chc.org) is that wet combing is the most reliable way to check for head lice because soaking wet lice stay still, but in dry hair lice move quickly from the disturbance.

Confirmation of head lice infestation

  • Expert opinion in a review article [Burgess, 2006] and a textbook [Ibarra, 1998] is that the presence of louse eggs, whether hatched (nits) or unhatched, are not proof of active infestation, as it is difficult to distinguish between dead and live eggs with the naked eye, and eggs may retain a viable appearance for weeks after death.
  • Expert opinion in guidelines [PHMEG, 2012; PHE, 2013; UKMI Cymru Wales, 2014] and a textbook [Ibarra, 1998] is that an itchy scalp is not enough to diagnose active infestation as itching:
    • May not develop for several weeks or months after the infestation.
    • May persist for days or weeks after the eradication of head lice.
    • Is a common reaction to hearing that there are head lice within the school or community.

  Checking all members of the household and close contacts

  • This recommendation is based on the fact that untreated family members and close contacts may cause reinfestation in the people who have been treated [Ibarra et al, 2007; PHMEG, 2012; BAD, 2014; UKMI Cymru Wales, 2014].
